question.body: Rudolfo anticipates a very busy semester, so he completes his entire C@CM course by the second week of the semester, passing each unit review test easily. While this frees up his time for other courses, he finds that when he goes to take the final exam five weeks later, he has forgotten a lot of what he learned. Rudolfo failed to .

fill_in_the_blank.choice: accurately evaluate his own strengths and weaknesses
plan an effective strategy for working through the course

response.feedback: Incorrect. Rudolfo successfully completed the work, so apparently he assessed the task accurately. It was his plan to complete the work too far in advance of the final exam that proved ineffective.

Correct. This could be one explanation, if Rudolfo overestimated his ability to remember material he had studied weeks earlier. However, it was primarily his plan to complete the work so far in advance of the final exam that proved ineffective.

Correct. Rudolfo’s plan to complete the work so far in advance of the final exam proved ineffective. Because he left five weeks between studying and taking the final exam, the material was not fresh in his mind when he took the final.

Incorrect. Rudolfo’s performance throughout the course was fine, so monitoring his performance was not his problem. It was his plan to complete the work too far in advance of the final exam that proved ineffective.

Incorrect. By the time Rudolfo realized his approach was unsuccessful, it was too late to adjust. This was because his plan to complete the work too far in advance of the final exam proved ineffective.

Consider, for example, that Rudolfo would have been better prepared for the final exam if he had scheduled regular work on C@CM throughout the semester.

question.body: Penelope has worked her way through the entire C@CM course by skipping the text and jumping straight to the activities, which she enjoys. When she doesn’t get an answer right on one of the activities, she just tries other answers until she discovers the correct one. Unfortunately, she does not pass the final exam the first time it’s offered, and thus has to learn the material all over again in time for the next final exam date. “Oh well,” she sighs: “Back to the drawing board.” Once again, she opens the first unit, skips the text, and goes straight to the activities. Penelope has failed to .

fill_in_the_blank.choice: accurately evaluate her own strengths and weaknesses
plan an effective strategy for working through the course

response.feedback: Incorrect. From the story, we can’t really know whether Penelope assessed the task inaccurately. What we do know is that she neither learned from her experience nor adjusted her approach for the next time.

Incorrect. This is possible, but not the best answer. True, if Penelope had accurately assessed her strengths and weaknesses the first time she worked through the course, she would have realized that she could not pass without reading the explanatory text. However, it was her failure to adjust her approach the second time that stands out here.

Incorrect. This is true, but not the best answer. Penelope did not plan an effective strategy for working through C@CM the first time. However, an even bigger mistake was not reflecting on and adjusting her approach after it failed.

Incorrect. While Penelope clearly did not monitor her performance closely enough to know her initial approach to studying was not effective, her bigger mistake was to employ the same approach the second time around.
Correct. This is the best answer: Penelope is employing the same unsuccessful approach the second time she takes the course, without learning from her mistakes the first time.

part.hint: Click on the definitions for each skill in the metacognitive cycle on the previous page to see if one looks like a match.
Notice that Penelope’s key decision point now is whether she will learn from her past approach to this unit and find a more effective way to go through the unit so she can learn the material.

question.body: Trevor jumps over the pre-assessment at the beginning of the Responsible Computing unit and dives straight into the text, reading all the explanatory content, doing all the activities, and completing the unit quiz. After acing the final exam, he complains to one of his friends: “I knew all that Responsible Computing stuff to begin with. I really don’t know why I had to do all that work.” Trevor could have saved himself time and effort if he had made an effort to .

fill_in_the_blank.choice: accurately evaluate his own strengths and weaknesses
plan an effective strategy for working through the course

response.feedback: Incorrect. We don’t know from reading this story if Trevor read the Responsible Computing unit objectives before beginning. What we do know is that he missed the opportunity to assess his own abilities in relation to those objectives. If he had done the pre-assessments and scored well, he would have realized that he didn’t need to read the text or do the exercises, and he could have saved time by skipping to the Exam-readiness Quiz at the end of the Responsible Computing unit.

Correct. If Trevor had done the pre-assessments – and realized that he didn’t need to read the text or do the exercises for the Responsible Computing Unit – he could have skipped ahead to the Exam-readiness Quiz and saved himself some time.

Incorrect. While Trevor may not have planned an efficient strategy, he lacked some key information to do so. If he had taken the pre-assessments – and realized that he didn’t need to read the text or do the exercises – he could have skipped ahead to the Exam-readiness Quiz and saved himself some time.

Incorrect. If Trevor had monitored his own performance better, he might have realized that the material was too easy for him and skipped ahead. However, doing the pre-assessments would have told him that up front, saving even more time.

Incorrect. Depending on the skills you have or need to gain, the best strategy for one unit may not be the best strategy for another unit. Thus, Trevor would have had trouble adjusting his approach without evaluating his own strengths and weaknesses.

part.hint: Click on the definitions for each skill in the metacognitive cycle on the previous page to see if one looks like a match.
Notice that Trevor didn’t consider his prior knowledge of the material until after he finished the whole course.

question.body: Margot doesn’t give much thought to how she approaches C@CM; she just goes to a unit, tries things, then takes the Exam-readiness Quiz. Sometimes she does well, sometimes she doesn’t. She’s really not sure how she’ll do on the final exam. Margot has not .

fill_in_the_blank.choice: evaluated her own strengths and weaknesses
planned a strategy for working through the course

response.feedback: Correct. Margot hasn't assesed the task at all.
Correct. Margot has not bothered evaluating her own strengths and weaknesses.
Correct. Margot really doesn’t have a strategy; she’s just trying things without giving her approach much thought.
Correct. Margot isn’t monitoring her own performance, which is why she has no idea what is and isn’t working, or how prepared she is for the final exam.
Correct. By failing to monitor her performance throughout the course, Margot has denied herself the opportunity to reflect and adjust her approach.

part.hint: Click on the definitions for each skill in the metacognitive cycle on the previous page to see if one looks like a match.
Notice that Margot has no idea how her various strategies are working.

question.body: Pablo has a busy semester, and he does not want to give too much time to C@CM. "After all, it’s just a pass/fail course," he thinks to himself. So he ignores the course all semester, figuring that he’ll spend an entire weekend at the end of the term working through the whole course. In the end, he fails the final exam. His principle mistake was that he did not .

fill_in_the_blank.choice: accurately evaluate his own strengths and weaknesses
plan an effective strategy for working through the course

response.feedback: Correct. Pablo underestimated the task, and left himself too little time to complete it. This underestimation is also reflected in his strategy: he has not planned appropriately.

Incorrect. Pablo ignored the course until the end of the semester. Because he did not bother to evaluate the task, he never had the opportunity to evaluate his own strengths and weaknesses in relation to it.
Correct. Pablo’s plan for working through his C@CM course did not allow sufficient time, mostly because of his inaccurate assessment of the task.
Incorrect. Pablo had limited opportunity to monitor his own performance because he failed to assess the task accurately and thus left all his work until the last minute.
Incorrect. The problem is not that Pablo didn't reflect back on his approach; the problem is that he failed to think ahead.

part.hint: Click on the definitions for each skill in the metacognitive cycle from the earlier page to see if one looks like a match.
Notice that Pablo may be in trouble because he hasn’t considered how long it will actually take to complete C@CM effectively.
